title: Buddha
description: A collection of sayings of the Buddha taken from the Dhammapada

verses.translation: Our life is shaped by our mind: it is ruled by our mind, it is made by our mind. If one speaks or acts with an evil mind, suf­fer­ing follows him, as the wheel follows the foot of the ox that draws the cart.
Our life is shaped by our mind: it is ruled by our mind, it is made by our mind. If one speaks or acts with a pure mind, hap­pi­ness follows him, like a shad­ow that nev­er leaves him.
“He insulted me, hit me, defeated me, robbed me.” In those who har­bor such thoughts, ha­tred will nev­er cease.
“He insulted me, hit me, defeated me, robbed me.” In those who do not har­bor such thoughts, ha­tred will cease.
For ha­tred nev­er ceases by ha­tred. Ha­tred ceases by love. This is an e­ter­nal law.
Some do not re­al­ize that we all must die, but those who do re­al­ize it cease their quarrels at once.
Just as the wind throws down a weak tree, so will the temp­ter o­ver­throw him who fo­cus­es on­ly on pleasures, his sen­ses un­con­trolled, im­mod­er­ate in his food, i­dle, and weak.

Just as the wind can­not throw down a rock­y moun­tain, so the temp­ter will not o­ver­throw him who does not fo­cus on pleasures, his sen­ses well con­trolled, mod­er­ate in his food, faith­ful and strong.
He who puts on the monkʼs yel­low robe with­out hav­ing cleansed him­self from sin, who disregards self-control and truth, is un­wor­thy of the robe.
But he who has cleansed him­self from sin, is well grounded in vir­tues, and regards self-control and truth, is in­deed wor­thy of the robe.
They who mis­take the triv­i­al for the es­sen­tial, and the es­sen­tial for the triv­i­al, nev­er ar­rive at the es­sen­tial, but fol­low vain desires.
They who know the es­sen­tial as es­sen­tial, and the triv­i­al as triv­i­al, ar­rive at the es­sen­tial, and fol­low true desires.
Just as rain seeps through a poor­ly tha­tched house, pas­sion seeps through an undeveloped mind.
Just as rain can­not seep through a well tha­tched house, pas­sion can­not seep through a well de­vel­oped mind.
The evil­do­er grieves in this world, and in the next. He grieves in both. He grieves and suffers when he sees the evil of his own work.
The vir­tu­ous man delights in this world, and in the next. He delights in both. He delights and rejoices when he sees the pu­ri­ty of his own work.
The evil­do­er suffers in this world, and in the next. He suffers in both. He suffers when he thinks of the evil he has done. He suffers more when go­ing to the next world.
The vir­tu­ous man is hap­py in this world, and in the next. He is hap­py in both. He is hap­py when he thinks of the good he has done. He is hap­pi­er still when go­ing to the next world.
The thought­less man, if he recites man­y scriptures, but does not do what they say, has no share in the blessings of the ho­ly life, but is like a cow­herd counting the cows of others.

He who recites on­ly a few scriptures, but does what they say, hav­ing for­sak­en lust and ha­tred and de­lu­sion, possesses true knowl­edge and se­ren­i­ty of mind, car­ing for noth­ing in this world or that to come, he shares in the blessings of the ho­ly life.
Vig­i­lance is the path to sal­va­tion. Care­less­ness is the path to death. Those who are vig­i­lant do not die. Those who are care­less are as if dead al­read­y.
The wise, hav­ing un­der­stood this clear­ly, de­light in vig­i­lance, and re­joice in the knowl­edge of the no­ble ones.
These wise peo­ple, meditative, stead­fast­ly per­se­ver­ing, at­tain to sal­va­tion, the highest hap­pi­ness.
If a vig­i­lant per­son is en­er­get­ic, if he is mind­ful, if his deeds are pure, if he acts with con­sid­er­a­tion, if he has self-control, and is right­eous, then his glo­ry will in­crease.
By ef­fort, by vig­i­lance, by dis­ci­pline and self-control, the wise man may make for him­self an is­land which no flood can o­ver­whelm.
The fool­ish and ig­no­rant in­dulge in care­less­ness. The wise man keeps vig­i­lance as his great­est treas­ure.
Do not give way to care­less­ness or to the en­joy­ment of sen­su­al pleasures. He who is vig­i­lant and meditative, obtains am­ple joy.

When the wise man drives a­way care­less­ness by vig­i­lance, he climbs the tow­er of wis­dom and looks down up­on the fools. With­out suf­fer­ing, he looks at the suf­fer­ing crowd, as one that stands on a moun­tain looks at them that stand on the ground be­low.
Vig­i­lant a­mong the care­less, a­wake a­mong the sleep­ing, the wise man ad­vanc­es like a fast horse, leav­ing the weak be­hind.
Vig­i­lance is al­ways praised; care­less­ness is al­ways de­spised.
The monk who delights in vig­i­lance, who looks with fear at care­less­ness, moves a­bout like fire, burn­ing all fetters, small and large.
The monk who delights in vig­i­lance, who looks with fear at care­less­ness, can­not fall a­way. He is close to sal­va­tion.
Just as a fletch­er straightens his ar­row, a wise man straightens his trem­bling and un­stead­y mind, which is dif­fi­cult to guard, dif­fi­cult to re­strain.
Just as a fish quivers when tak­en from its home in the wa­ter and thrown on land, our mind trem­bles all o­ver to es­cape the in­flu­ence of the temp­ter.
It is good to tame the mind, which is dif­fi­cult to tame and flight­y, rush­ing wher­ev­er it wants. A tamed mind brings hap­pi­ness.
Let the wise man guard his mind, for it is sub­tle and e­lu­sive, and it rushes wher­ev­er it wants. A guard­ed mind brings hap­pi­ness.
The mind wanders far, moves a­bout a­lone, is with­out a bod­y, and hides in the ca­ve of the heart. Those who bri­dle it are free from the bonds of the temp­ter.
If a manʼs mind is un­stead­y, if he does not know the true law, and if his faith is troubled, then his knowl­edge will nev­er be per­fect.
If a manʼs mind is free from pas­sion, if his mind is free from ill will, if he is un­af­fect­ed by good and evil, then there is dan­ger for him.

Know­ing that this bod­y is frag­ile like a clay pot, and securing this mind like a for­tress, at­tack the temp­ter with the sword of knowl­edge. Then guard what is won with­out feel­ing at­tach­ment to it.
Soon, this bod­y will lie on the ground, discarded, with­out con­scious­ness, like a use­less log.
What­ev­er an en­e­my might do to an en­e­my, or a foe to a foe, a wrong­ly di­rect­ed mind can do to you e­ven worse.
What­ev­er a moth­er, a fa­ther, or any oth­er rel­a­tive might do for you, a well di­rect­ed mind can do for you e­ven more.
Who will o­ver­come this earth, and the world of the dead, and the world of the gods? Who will choose the well taught path of vir­tue, as an ex­pert flo­rist chooses the right flow­er?

A dis­ci­ple will o­ver­come this earth, and the world of the dead, and the world of the gods. A dis­ci­ple will choose the well taught path of vir­tue, as an ex­pert flo­rist chooses the right flow­er.
Know­ing that this bod­y is like froth, and learn­ing that it is in­sub­stan­tial like a mi­rage, you will re­move the flower-tipped ar­rows of the temp­ter, and nev­er see the king of death.
As a flood sweeps a­way a sleep­ing vil­lage, so death sweeps a­way a man who is im­mersed in gath­er­ing flowers, his mind dis­tract­ed.
Death subdues a man who is im­mersed in gath­er­ing flowers, his mind dis­tract­ed, be­fore he is sa­ti­at­ed in his pleasures.
As a bee collects nec­tar and departs with­out dam­ag­ing the flow­er or its col­or or its scent, so should a sage col­lect alms in a vil­lage.
Do not no­tice the faults of others, their sins of com­mis­sion or o­mis­sion, but no­tice your own mis­con­duct and neg­li­gence.
Like a beau­ti­ful flow­er, full of col­or but with­out scent, are fair but fruit­less words of him who does not prac­tice them.
But, like a beau­ti­ful flow­er, full of col­or and full of scent, are fair and fruit­ful words of him who practices them.
Just as man­y wreaths can be made from a heap of flowers, so can man­y good things be done by a mor­tal.

The scent of flowers does not trav­el a­gainst the wind, not e­ven that of san­dal­wood, tagara or jas­mine; but the rep­u­ta­tion of the vir­tu­ous does trav­el a­gainst the wind. The rep­u­ta­tion of the vir­tu­ous pervades eve­ry place.
A­mong the scent of san­dal­wood, tagara, lo­tus, and jas­mine, the scent of vir­tue is un­sur­passed.
The scent that co­mes from tagara and san­dal­wood is faint. The scent of the vir­tu­ous is best, it rises up to the gods.
The temp­ter nev­er finds the path of the vir­tu­ous, who lives with vig­i­lance, and is freed through per­fect knowl­edge.
On a gar­bage heap by the roadside, a lo­tus grows full of sweet per­fume and de­light.
Like­wise, on a gar­bage heap of blind mortals, a true dis­ci­ple of the Bud­dha shines forth in wis­dom.
The night is long to the sleep­less; a mile is long to the tired; life is long to the fool­ish who do not know the true law.
If a trav­el­er does not meet a com­pan­ion who is his bet­ter, or his e­qual, let him firm­ly keep to his sol­i­tar­y jour­ney. There is no com­pan­ion­ship with a fool.
He worries, “I have sons, and I have wealth,” but he him­self is not his own, how much less sons and wealth?
A fool who knows his own fool­ish­ness, is wise to that ex­tent. But a fool who thinks he is wise, is a fool in­deed.
E­ven if a fool associates with a wise man all his life, he will per­ceive the truth no more than a spoon perceives the fla­vor of the soup.
If an in­tel­li­gent man associates with a wise man for on­ly one min­ute, he will soon per­ceive the truth as the tongue perceives the taste of soup.
Fools of lit­tle un­der­stand­ing are their own enemies, for they do evil deeds that bear bit­ter fruit.
That deed is poor­ly done if a man must re­pent af­ter­ward, and its re­ward is cry­ing and a tear­ful face.
That deed is well done if a man does not re­pent af­ter­ward, and its re­ward is de­light and hap­pi­ness.
As long as an evil deed does not bear fruit, the fool thinks it is like hon­ey. But when it ripens, then the fool suffers grief.
E­ven if a fool, month af­ter month, eats his food like an as­cet­ic with the tip of a blade of grass, he is not worth e­ven one six­teenth of those who have un­der­stood the truth.
An evil deed, like fresh­ly drawn milk, does not sour im­me­di­ate­ly; it follows the fool, smoldering, like fire cov­ered by ash­es.
The fool wishes for a false rep­u­ta­tion, for prec­e­dence a­mong monks, for au­thor­i­ty in the monasteries, for hon­or a­mong oth­er peo­ple.
“May both laymen and monks think that I did it. Let them o­bey me in eve­ry­thing, great and small.” Such is the mind of the fool, and thus his de­sire and pride in­crease.
One road leads to wealth, an­oth­er road leads to sal­va­tion. If the monk, a dis­ci­ple of Bud­dha, has learn­ed this, he will not yearn for hon­or, he will strive for sep­a­ra­tion from the world.
If you find a wise man who points out faults, and who reproves, fol­low that wise man as one would fol­low a guide to hid­den treas­ure. It will be bet­ter, not worse, for those who fol­low him.
Let him ad­mon­ish, let him teach, let him re­strain you from what is im­prop­er. The good will love him. The bad will hate him.
Do not have evildoers as companions, do not have vile peo­ple as friends. Have vir­tu­ous peo­ple as companions, have the best as friends.
He who drinks in the law lives hap­pi­ly with a se­rene mind. The wise man rejoices al­ways in the law, as preached by the no­ble ones.
Irrigators guide the wa­ter. Fletchers straight­en the ar­row. Carpenters shape the wood. The wise con­trol them­selves.
Just as a sol­id rock is not shak­en by the wind, the wise do not fal­ter a­midst blame or praise.
Af­ter they have listened to the law, the wise be­come se­rene, like a deep, smooth, and still lake.
The good keep walk­ing what­ev­er happens. The good do not prat­tle, long­ing for pleas­ure. Wheth­er touched by hap­pi­ness or sor­row, the wise nev­er ap­pear e­lat­ed or de­pressed.

A man is good, wise, and vir­tu­ous if he does no wrong for his own sa­ke or for the sa­ke of others, if he wishes nei­ther for wealth, a son, or a king­dom, and if he does not wish for suc­cess by un­fair means.
Few a­mong men ar­rive at the oth­er shore (sal­va­tion). The rest run up and down on this shore.
But those who fol­low the law, when it has been well taught to them, will ar­rive at the oth­er shore hav­ing crossed the do­min­ion of death, how­ev­er dif­fi­cult to o­ver­come.
Let a wise man leave the dark way, and fol­low the bright path. Af­ter go­ing from his home to home­less­ness, let him yearn for de­light in de­tach­ment, so dif­fi­cult to en­joy.
Leav­ing all pleasures be­hind, and call­ing noth­ing his own, let the wise man cleanse him­self of that which defiles the mind.

Those whose minds are well grounded in the factors of en­light­en­ment, who with­out cling­ing to any­thing, re­joice in free­dom from at­tach­ment, whose appetites have been conquered, and who are full of light, are free e­ven in this world.
There is no suf­fer­ing for him who has fin­ished his jour­ney, and is with­out sor­row, and is free on all sides, and has thrown off all fetters.
The mind­ful strive dil­i­gent­ly. They are not at­tached to any home. Like swans who leave a lake, they leave their house and home.
Like birds in the air, the path of the saint is hard to trace. They have no rich­es, are wise re­gard­ing food, and their ob­jec­tive is emp­ti­ness and free­dom.
Like birds in the air, his path is hard to trace. He whose appetites are stilled, who is not at­tached to food, whose ob­jec­tive is emp­ti­ness and free­dom.
E­ven the gods a­dore him whose sen­ses have been sub­dued, like hors­es well trained by a char­i­ot­eer, who is free from pride, and free from appetites.
Like the earth, he is not pro­voked. He is firm like a pil­lar. He is like a pure lake with­out mud. No new births are in store for him.
His mind is calm, and calm are his words and deeds. By true knowl­edge, he has obtained free­dom, and thus be­come tran­quil.
In a vil­lage or in a for­est, in a val­ley or on a hill, wher­ev­er saints dwell, that place is de­light­ful.
De­light­ful are the forests in which the crowds find no pleas­ure. Those with­out pas­sion will find de­light there, for they do not seek pleas­ure.
Bet­ter than a speech of a thou­sand vain words, is one thought­ful word, hear­ing which brings peace.
Bet­ter than a po­em of a thou­sand vain verses, is one thought­ful verse, hear­ing which brings peace.
Bet­ter than re­cit­ing a hun­dred vain verses, is re­cit­ing one verse of law, hear­ing which brings peace.
Greater than he who conquers a thou­sand times a thou­sand men in bat­tle, is he who conquerors just one — him­self.
It is far bet­ter to con­quer one­self than to con­quer others.
For a man who has conquered him­self and al­ways lives with self-control, not e­ven a god, an an­gel, or a de­mon with a god can change that vic­to­ry in­to de­feat.

A man could sac­ri­fice by the thousands for month af­ter month for a hun­dred years, or he could pay hom­age for one mo­ment to a man liv­ing in wis­dom. Bet­ter is that hom­age than sacrifices for a cen­tu­ry.

A man could tend the sac­ri­fi­cial fire in the for­est for a hun­dred years, or he could pay hom­age for one mo­ment to a man liv­ing in wis­dom. Bet­ter is that hom­age than sacrifices for a cen­tu­ry.
In this world, a man may make sacrifices and oblations for a whole year in or­der to gain mer­it, yet all of it is not worth a quar­ter of the mer­it gained by re­ver­ing the right­eous.
For him who al­ways respects and hon­ors the wise, four things will in­crease: life, beau­ty, hap­pi­ness, pow­er.
Bet­ter than a hun­dred years lived im­mor­al and un­re­strained, is one day lived vir­tu­ous and reflecting.
Bet­ter than a hun­dred years lived ig­no­rant and un­re­strained, is one day lived wise and reflecting.
Bet­ter than a hun­dred years i­dle and weak, is one day lived en­er­get­ic and firm.
Bet­ter than a hun­dred years lived with­out see­ing be­gin­ning or end, is one day lived see­ing be­gin­ning and end.
Bet­ter than a hun­dred years lived with­out see­ing the death­less state, is one day lived see­ing the death­less state.
Bet­ter than a hun­dred years lived with­out see­ing the highest law, is one day lived see­ing the highest law.
Has­ten to do good. Keep your mind from evil. If a man is slow to do good, his mind delights in evil.
If a man does what is evil, let him not do it a­gain and a­gain. Let him not de­light in it, for ac­cu­mu­lat­ing evil brings pain.
If a man does what is good, let him do it a­gain and a­gain. Let him de­light in it, for ac­cu­mu­lat­ing good brings joy.
E­ven an evil­do­er may be hap­py be­fore his evil deed ripens, but when it ripens, he suffers.
E­ven a good man may suf­fer be­fore his good deed ripens, but when it ripens, he is hap­py.

Let no man think light­ly of evil, say­ing in his heart, “It will not a­mount to much.” As a wa­ter pot is filled by the fall­ing of wa­ter drops, so the fool becomes full of evil, e­ven if he gathers it lit­tle by lit­tle.

Let no man think light­ly of good, say­ing in his heart, “It will not a­mount to much.” As a wa­ter pot is filled by the fall­ing of wa­ter drops, so the wise man becomes full of good, e­ven if he gathers it lit­tle by lit­tle.
Let a man a­void evil deeds, as a wealth­y mer­chant with few companions avoids a dan­ger­ous road; as a man who loves life avoids poi­son.
If a man offends a harm­less, pure, and in­no­cent per­son, the evil falls back up­on that fool, like dust thrown a­gainst the wind.
Some are born in the womb. Evildoers go to hell. The right­eous go to heav­en. Those with­out any world­ly desires at­tain sal­va­tion.
Not in the sky, not in the mid­dle of the sea, not in a cleft of the mountains, is there a spot to be found where a man can es­cape from the con­se­quenc­es of his evil deed.
Not in the sky, not in the mid­dle of the sea, not in a cleft of the mountains, is there a spot to be found where a man will not be o­ver­come by death.
Eve­ry­one trem­bles at pun­ish­ment, eve­ry­one fears death. Put­ting your­self in his place, do not kill or cause others to kill.
Eve­ry­one trem­bles at pun­ish­ment, eve­ry­one loves his own life. Put­ting your­self in his place, do not kill or cause others to kill.
He who, seek­ing hap­pi­ness, punishes beings who al­so de­sire hap­pi­ness, will not find hap­pi­ness af­ter death.
He who, seek­ing hap­pi­ness, does not pun­ish beings who al­so de­sire hap­pi­ness, will find hap­pi­ness af­ter death.
Speak harsh­ly to no one, or those who are spo­ken to will an­swer you in the same way. Con­ten­tious speech hurts, and re­tal­i­a­tion will come to you.
If your mind is still, like a bro­ken gong, you have attained sal­va­tion, for thereʼs no con­ten­tion in you.
As a cow­herd drives cows to pas­ture with a staff, so age­ing and death drive the life of men.
A fool does not re­al­ize when he commits evil, but he suffers for those deeds, as if burned by fire.
He who inflicts pain on the in­no­cent and un­armed, will soon suf­fer in one of these ten ways:
se­vere pain, im­pov­er­ish­ment, bod­i­ly in­ju­ry, se­ri­ous ill­ness, men­tal ill­ness,
trou­ble from the gov­ern­ment, a fear­ful ac­cu­sa­tion, loss of relatives, loss of wealth,
or fire will de­stroy his hous­es. When his bod­y is destroyed, the fool will go to hell.
Nei­ther na­ked­ness, nor mat­ted hair, nor dirt, nor fasting, nor ly­ing on the earth, nor rub­bing with dust, nor sit­ting mo­tion­less, can pu­ri­fy a mor­tal who has not o­ver­come doubt.

He who exercises tran­quil­i­ty, is qui­et, sub­dued, restrained, chaste, and has set a­side vi­o­lence to­wards all others, he in­deed is a ho­ly man, an as­cet­ic, a monk, e­ven if dressed in fi­ne ap­par­el.
Who in this world is so restrained by con­science that he needs no re­proof, as a fi­ne horse needs no whip?

Like a fi­ne horse when touched by the whip, be ac­tive and live­ly. By faith, by vir­tue, by ef­fort, by med­i­ta­tion, by dis­cern­ing the truth, by per­fect knowl­edge and con­duct, by mind­ful­ness, you will leave this pain be­hind.
Irrigators guide the wa­ter. Fletchers straight­en the ar­row. Carpenters shape the wood. Good peo­ple fash­ion them­selves.
Why is there laugh­ter and joy when this world is al­ways burn­ing? Surrounded by dark­ness, donʼt you look for a light?
Look at this bod­y — a paint­ed im­age, cov­ered with festering wounds, sick­ly, full of man­y thoughts — nei­ther last­ing nor sta­ble.
This bod­y is worn out, full of sick­ness, and frail. This heap of cor­rup­tion breaks to pieces, for life in­deed ends with death.
These white bones are like gourds thrown a­way in the au­tumn. What pleas­ure is there in see­ing them?
A cit­y made of bones is cov­ered with flesh and blood. Liv­ing in it are old age and death, pride and de­ceit.
The beau­ti­ful chariots of kings get worn out and so does the bod­y. But the vir­tue of good peo­ple does not age: thus do the good say a­mong them­selves.
A man who has learn­ed lit­tle grows old like an ox. His bod­y grows, but his wis­dom does not.
I roamed through man­y births, with­out re­ward and with­out rest, looking for the build­er of this house. Pain­ful is birth a­gain and a­gain.

But now, build­er of this house, I have seen you. You will not build this house a­gain. All your rafters are bro­ken, your ridge pole is dismantled. My mind has attained the ex­tinc­tion of all desires.
Those who, in their youth, have not lived the ho­ly life nor gained wealth, per­ish like old herons in a lake with­out fish.
Those who, in their youth, have not lived the ho­ly life nor gained wealth, lie sighing o­ver the past like ar­rows misfired from a bow.
If a man holds him­self dear, let him watch him­self care­ful­ly. Let a wise man keep vig­il dur­ing one of the three watches of the night.
Let each man first di­rect him­self to what is prop­er, then let him teach others. Thus a wise man will not be reproached.
If a man makes him­self as he teaches others to be, then, be­ing him­self well tamed, he may tame others. Oneʼs self is in­deed dif­fi­cult to tame.
A man is tru­ly his own pro­tec­tor. Who else could be the pro­tec­tor? With self well con­trolled, one finds a pro­tec­tor such as few can find.
The evil a fool­ish man does by him­self, self-born, self-created, grinds him down, as a dia­mond breaks a hard gem.
When o­ver­spread with great wick­ed­ness, like a tree cov­ered by vines, a man brings him­self down to where his en­e­my wishes.
Evil deeds, which harm our­selves, are eas­y to do. Good and ben­e­fi­cial deeds are ver­y dif­fi­cult to do.
The fool who scorns the teachings of the wise, of the no­ble, of the right­eous, and follows false doc­trine, is like the bam­boo that dies af­ter bear­ing fruit.
Evil is done by one­self, by one­self one is de­filed. Evil is left un­done by one­self, by one­self is one pu­ri­fied. Pu­ri­ty and im­pu­ri­ty are oneʼs own do­ing. No one can pu­ri­fy an­oth­er.
Let no man sac­ri­fice his own wel­fare for that of an­oth­er, how­ev­er great. Let a man, af­ter dis­cern­ing his own wel­fare, be al­ways at­ten­tive to it.
Do not fol­low vul­gar ways. Do not live with a­ban­don. Do not fol­low false doc­trine. Do not be a friend of the world.
Wake up! Do not be i­dle. Live a vir­tu­ous life. The vir­tu­ous sleeps with ease in this world and the next.
Live a vir­tu­ous life. Do not live a life of sin. The vir­tu­ous sleeps with ease in this world and the next.
The king of death does not see him who looks up­on the world as a bub­ble, as a mi­rage.
Come look at this world, dec­o­rat­ed like a roy­al char­i­ot. Fools are im­mersed in it, but the wise do not cling to it.
He who was reck­less and then becomes mind­ful, brightens up this world like the moon when freed from clouds.
He who replaces evil deeds with good deeds, brightens up this world, like the moon when freed from clouds.
In this dark world, on­ly a few can see. On­ly a few, like birds es­cap­ing from the net, go to heav­en.
Swans fly on the path of the sun, through the air by their won­der­ful pow­er. The wise flee from the world af­ter defeating the temp­ter and his armies.
A man who transgresses the one law, speaks lies, and scoffs at the world be­yond, is ca­pa­ble of any evil.
Misers do not go to the world of the gods; nei­ther do fools praise gen­er­os­i­ty. A wise man rejoices in gen­er­os­i­ty, and through it becomes bless­ed in the world be­yond.
The first step to­wards ho­li­ness is bet­ter than sov­er­eign­ty o­ver the earth, bet­ter than go­ing to heav­en, and bet­ter than be­ing lord o­ver all the worlds.
E­ven the gods en­vy those who are awakened, who are de­vot­ed to med­i­ta­tion, who are wise, and who de­light in the calm of re­nun­ci­a­tion.
It is dif­fi­cult to ob­tain a hu­man birth, dif­fi­cult is the life of mortals. It is dif­fi­cult to ob­tain the chance to hear the true law, dif­fi­cult is the birth of the awakened.
To a­void all evil, to cul­ti­vate good, and to pu­ri­fy oneʼs mind, that is the teach­ing of the awakened.
Pa­tient en­dur­ance is the highest aus­ter­i­ty. “Sal­va­tion is su­preme”, say the awakened. He is no monk who injures others. He is no as­cet­ic who insults others.
Not to re­vile, not to in­jure, to live restrained un­der the law, to be mod­er­ate in food, to live in sol­i­tude, and to dwell on the highest thoughts: this is the teach­ing of the awakened.
There is no way to sat­is­fy lusts, e­ven with a show­er of gold coins. He is wise who knows that lusts give lit­tle sat­is­fac­tion and much pain.
E­ven in heav­en­ly pleasures the wise finds no de­light. The dis­ci­ple who is ful­ly awakened delights on­ly in the de­struc­tion of crav­ing.
When threatened with dan­ger, men go to man­y a ref­uge: to mountains and forests, to groves and shrines.
But that is not a se­cure ref­uge, that is not the best ref­uge. A man is not delivered from all pain af­ter go­ing to that ref­uge.
He who takes ref­uge with the law, the awakened, and their or­der, sees with clear un­der­stand­ing the four ho­ly truths:
pain, the cause of pain, the de­struc­tion of pain, and the ho­ly eight­fold path that leads to the quieting of pain;
That is a se­cure ref­uge, that is the best ref­uge. Af­ter go­ing to that ref­uge, a man is delivered from all pain.
An awakened man is hard to find. He is not born eve­ry­where. Wher­ev­er such a wise man is born, that clan prospers.
Bless­ed is the arising of awakened ones, bless­ed is the teach­ing of the true law, bless­ed is har­mo­ny in the or­der, bless­ed is the de­vo­tion of those who are at peace.
He who reveres those who de­serve rev­er­ence — the awakened ones or their disciples, who have o­ver­come all obstacles, sor­row, and lam­en­ta­tion,
who found de­liv­er­ance and know no fear — his mer­it can nev­er be meas­ured.
We live hap­pi­ly, not hat­ing those who hate us. When a­mong men who hate us, we dwell with­out ha­tred.
We live hap­pi­ly, with­out ill­ness a­mong the ill. When a­mong men who are ill, we dwell with­out ill­ness.
We live hap­pi­ly, with­out greed a­mong the greed­y. When a­mong men who are greed­y, we dwell with­out greed.
We live hap­pi­ly, we who own noth­ing.
Vic­to­ry breeds ha­tred, for the conquered live in pain. The con­tent­ed is hap­py, hav­ing giv­en up both vic­to­ry and de­feat.
There is no fire like lust, no loss like ha­tred, no pain like this ex­ist­ence, and no hap­pi­ness higher than peace.
Hun­ger is the worst dis­ease, this ex­ist­ence the great­est pain. If one tru­ly knows this, he realizes sal­va­tion, the highest hap­pi­ness.
Health is the great­est gift, con­tent­ment the great­est wealth. Trust is the best kins­man, sal­va­tion the highest hap­pi­ness.
He who has savored the taste of sol­i­tude and tran­quil­i­ty is free from fear and evil, refreshed with the nour­ish­ment of the law.
The sight of no­ble ones is good. To live with them is al­ways hap­pi­ness. If a man does not see fools, he will be tru­ly hap­py.
He who walks with fools suffers for a long time. Com­pa­ny with fools, as with an en­e­my, is al­ways pain­ful. Com­pa­ny with the wise is a pleas­ure, like re­un­ion with fam­i­ly.
There­fore, fol­low the wise, the in­tel­li­gent, the learn­ed, the stead­fast, the du­ti­ful, the no­ble. Fol­low a good and dis­cern­ing man, as the moon follows the path of the stars.
He who gives him­self to van­i­ty, in­stead of to med­i­ta­tion, who forgets the goal and grasps at pleas­ure, will come to en­vy him who has exerted him­self.
Donʼt seek for what is pleas­ant or un­pleas­ant, for it is pain not to see the pleas­ant, and it is pain to see what is un­pleas­ant.
There­fore, let no man hold any­thing dear, for loss of the dear is pain­ful. Those who hold noth­ing dear and hate noth­ing have no fetters.
From pleas­ure co­mes grief, from pleas­ure co­mes fear. He who is free from pleas­ure knows nei­ther grief nor fear.
From af­fec­tion co­mes grief, from af­fec­tion co­mes fear. He who is free from af­fec­tion knows nei­ther grief nor fear.
From at­tach­ment co­mes grief, from at­tach­ment co­mes fear. He who is free from at­tach­ment knows nei­ther grief nor fear.
From lust co­mes grief, from lust co­mes fear. He who is free from lust knows nei­ther grief nor fear.
From crav­ing co­mes grief, from crav­ing co­mes fear. He who is free from crav­ing knows nei­ther grief nor fear.
He who has vir­tue and in­sight, who is just, who speaks the truth, and does his own busi­ness, him the world holds dear.
He who is in­tent up­on sal­va­tion, who is sat­is­fied in his mind, and who is not at­tached to pleas­ure, is called “car­ried up­stream”.
Fam­i­ly, friends, and well-wishers wel­come a man, long ab­sent, who returns safe­ly from a­far.
As fam­i­ly receives a friend on his re­turn, so do his good works wel­come him who has done good, and has gone from this world to the next.
Let a man leave an­ger, for­sake pride, and o­ver­come all bond­age. No suf­fer­ing befalls the man who is de­tached from name and form, and who calls noth­ing his own.
I call him a mas­ter char­i­ot­eer who holds back ris­ing an­ger like a rac­ing char­i­ot. Others mere­ly hold the reins.
O­ver­come an­ger with love, evil with good, greed with gen­er­os­i­ty, and lies with truth.
Speak the truth, do not yield to an­ger, and give, if asked, e­ven if itʼs on­ly a lit­tle. By these three steps you will go near the gods.
The sages who harm no one, and al­ways con­trol their bod­y, go to the un­change­a­ble state, where they suf­fer no more.
Those who are al­ways vig­i­lant, stud­y­ing day and night, in­tent on sal­va­tion, their passions fade a­way.
This is an old say­ing, not just of to­day: “They blame him who is si­lent, they blame him who speaks much, they blame him who speaks lit­tle.” There is none on earth who escapes blame.
There nev­er was, there nev­er will be, nor is there now, a man who is al­ways blamed or al­ways praised.
If the knowl­edge­a­ble praise him, hav­ing ob­served him day af­ter day to be with­out blem­ish, wise, and rich in knowl­edge and vir­tue,
like an in­got of gold, who can blame him? E­ven the gods praise him. E­ven the Cre­a­tor praises him.
With your bod­y: be­ware of an­ger, be restrained, leave its sins, and with it prac­tise vir­tue.
With your tongue: be­ware of an­ger, be restrained, leave its sins, and prac­tise vir­tue.
With your mind: be­ware of an­ger, be restrained, leave its sins, and prac­tise vir­tue.
The wise who con­trol their bod­y, their tongue, and their mind, are well con­trolled in­deed.
You are now like a withered leaf, the messengers of death stand near­by. You stand at the door of de­par­ture, yet have no pro­vi­sion for your jour­ney.
Make an is­land for your­self, work hard, be wise. When your impurities are blown a­way, and you are free from guilt, you will en­ter in­to the heav­en­ly world of the e­lect.
Your life has come to an end, you are near death, there is no rest­ing place for you on the road, yet you have no pro­vi­sion for your jour­ney.
Make an is­land for your­self, work hard, be wise. When your impurities are blown a­way, and you are free from guilt, you will not en­ter a­gain in­to birth and de­cay.
Let a wise man re­move his own impurities, as a smith removes impurities from sil­ver one by one, lit­tle by lit­tle, and mo­ment by mo­ment.
Just as rust destroys the i­ron from which it springs, so do a transgressorʼs deeds lead him to an evil des­ti­na­tion.
The im­pu­ri­ty of prayers is not re­cit­ing them. The im­pu­ri­ty of hous­es is not repairing them. The im­pu­ri­ty of beau­ty is sloth. The im­pu­ri­ty of a watch­man is mind­less­ness.
Sex­u­al mis­con­duct is the im­pu­ri­ty of wom­an, stin­gi­ness the im­pu­ri­ty of a do­nor. All evil ways are impurities, both in this world and in the next.
But there is an im­pu­ri­ty worse than all others: ig­no­rance. O monks, throw off that im­pu­ri­ty to be­come pure.
Life is eas­y for a shame­less man, who is cun­ning as a crow, who makes mis­chief, and is in­sult­ing, ar­ro­gant, and cor­rupt.
But life is hard for a mod­est man, who al­ways seeks pu­ri­ty, is dis­in­ter­est­ed, qui­et, spot­less, and ob­ser­vant.
He who destroys life, speaks lies, takes what is not giv­en, goes to an­oth­er manʼs wife,
and gives him­self to in­tox­i­cat­ing liq­uor, he digs up his own root here in this world.
Know this, good man, that evil is hard to con­trol. Do not let greed and vi­ce bring you to prolonged grief.
Peo­ple give ac­cord­ing to their faith or con­vic­tion. If a man worries a­bout the food and drink giv­en to others, he will find no rest by day or night.
He in whom that feel­ing is cut down, uprooted, and destroyed, finds rest by day and night.
There is no fire like pas­sion, no grip like ha­tred, no snare like de­lu­sion, no riv­er like crav­ing.
It is eas­y to see the faults of others, but dif­fi­cult to see oneʼs own. A man winnows the faults of others like chaff, but hides his own, like a cheat hides an un­luck­y throw of the dice.
If a man fo­cus­es on the errors of others, and is al­ways in­clined to find fault, his own faults will grow, and he is far from destroying them.
The world delights in van­i­ty, but the awakened are free from it.
No crea­ture is e­ter­nal, but the awakened are nev­er shak­en.
A man does not be­come just by pass­ing ar­bi­trar­y judge­ment. No, he is called just who weighs both right and wrong,
who judges im­par­tial­ly and with­out hur­ry, in line with law, guarding the law, guard­ed by the law, and who is in­tel­li­gent.
A man is not wise just be­cause he talks a lot. He is called wise who is pa­tient, and free from hos­til­i­ty and fear.
A man does not up­hold the law just be­cause he talks a lot. He who has learn­ed on­ly a lit­tle of the law, yet comprehends it and nev­er neglects it, he upholds the law.
A man is not an eld­er just be­cause his hair is grey. He may be ad­vanced in years, but is called “one grown old in vain.”
He in whom there is truth, vir­tue, love, re­straint, self con­trol, who is free from im­pu­ri­ty, and is wise, he is called an eld­er.
El­o­quence or phys­i­cal beau­ty do not make an en­vi­ous, greed­y, dis­hon­est man re­spect­a­ble.
He is called re­spect­a­ble when all these are cut down, uprooted, and destroyed, when he is free from ha­tred, and is wise.
An un­dis­ci­plined man who speaks lies does not be­come a monk just by shav­ing his head. How can he be a monk who is held cap­tive by de­sire and greed?
He who quiets evil, both small and large, is called a monk, be­cause he has o­ver­come all evil.
A man is not a monk just be­cause he asks for alms. He who adopts the whole law is a monk.
He who is a­bove both good and evil, who is chaste, and who goes through the world with un­der­stand­ing, he in­deed is called a monk.
A fool­ish and ig­no­rant man does not be­come a sage just by si­lence. But the wise, as if hold­ing the scales, chooses good and avoids evil.
For this rea­son he is a sage. He who weighs both sides of this world is called a sage.
A man does not be­come no­ble by harming liv­ing creatures. He is called no­ble for harming no liv­ing thing.
Not by rules and practices, not by much learn­ing, not by great con­cen­tra­tion, not by life in se­clu­sion,
not by think­ing, “I en­joy the hap­pi­ness of re­nun­ci­a­tion which no world­ling can know”, should the monk be con­fi­dent with­out attaining the ex­tinc­tion of desires.
Of paths, the Eight­fold is best. Of truths, the Four No­ble are best. Of vir­tues, de­tach­ment is best. Of men, he who has eyes to see is best.
This is the on­ly path, there is no oth­er, to pu­ri­fy vi­sion. Fol­low this path and it will be­wil­der the temp­ter.
Fol­low­ing this path will end pain. Once I un­der­stood how to re­move thorns in the flesh, I preached this path.
You your­self must make an ef­fort. Buddhas on­ly show the way. The thought­ful who fol­low the path are freed from the tempterʼs bonds.
“All cre­at­ed things are tem­po­rar­y.” He who sees and knows this turns a­way from pain. This is the path to pu­ri­ty.
“All cre­at­ed things are pain­ful.” He who sees and knows this turns a­way from pain. This is the path to pu­ri­ty.
He who does not ex­ert him­self when it is time, who, though young and strong, is full of sloth, whose will and mind are weak, that la­zy and i­dle man will nev­er find the path to knowl­edge.
Let a man watch his speech, be well restrained in mind, and nev­er com­mit wrong with his bod­y. If a man purifies these three cours­es of ac­tion, he will a­chieve the path taught by the wise.
Zeal brings knowl­edge. Lack of zeal loses knowl­edge. Know­ing these two paths of gain and loss, let a man con­duct him­self so that knowl­edge may grow.
Cut down the whole for­est of de­sire, not just one tree. Dan­ger co­mes from the for­est. Once you have cut down this for­est and its un­der­growth, monks, you will be free.
As long as the smallest crav­ing of man for wom­an is not destroyed, his mind is in bond­age, as the suck­ing calf to its moth­er.
Cut out the love of self, like an au­tumn lo­tus with your hand. Cher­ish the road of peace, sal­va­tion, as shown by the awakened.
“I will live here dur­ing the rains, and o­ver here in win­ter and sum­mer.” Thus thinks the fool, un­a­ware of obstructions.
Death carries off the man, praised for his chil­dren and flocks, his mind dis­tract­ed, as a flood carries off a sleep­ing vil­lage.
For him whom death has seized, kinsmen are no pro­tec­tion. Nei­ther sons, a fa­ther, nor re­la­tions can give shel­ter.
Know­ing this, a wise and good man should quick­ly clear the path lead­ing to sal­va­tion.
If by leav­ing a small pleas­ure one sees a great pleas­ure, let a wise man leave the small pleas­ure and look to the great.
He who seeks pleas­ure for him­self by caus­ing pain to others is entangled by the bonds of ha­tred, and can­not be free from ha­tred.
Desires al­ways in­crease for un­ru­ly, heed­less peo­ple who ne­glect what should be done and do what should not be done.

But desires will come to an end for watch­ful, wise peo­ple who do not do what should not be done, who stead­fast­ly do what should be done, and whose whole watch­ful­ness is al­ways di­rect­ed to their bod­y.
The disciples of Gotama are wide a­wake and vig­i­lant, and their minds day and night are al­ways set on the Awakened,
on the law,
on the church,
and on their bod­y.
The disciples of Gotama are wide a­wake and vig­i­lant, and their minds day and night al­ways de­light in com­pas­sion,
and in med­i­ta­tion.

It is hard to be a monk. It is hard to en­joy that life. House­hold life is al­so hard and pain­ful. It is pain­ful to dwell with unequals and the wan­der­ing monk is be­set with pain. There­fore let no man wan­der aim­less­ly and he will not be be­set with pain.
A faith­ful, vir­tu­ous, rep­u­ta­ble, and wealth­y man is respected wher­ev­er he goes.
Like the Himalayas, good peo­ple shine from a­far. Like ar­rows shot by night, bad peo­ple are un­seen e­ven when they are near.
He who sits a­lone, sleeps a­lone, walks a­lone, is dil­i­gent, and subdues him­self a­lone, will re­joice in the sol­i­tude of the for­est.
He goes to hell, the one who asserts what did­nʼt hap­pen, and the one who did a thing but says, “I have not done it”. They are both evildoers, and are e­qual in the next world.
Man­y men who wear the saf­fron robe are ill-mannered and un­re­strained. Such evildoers by their evil deeds go to hell.
It would be bet­ter to swal­low an i­ron ball, red-hot and a­flame, than for an im­mor­al, un­re­strained man to eat the alms of the peo­ple.
A wreckless man who lies down with his neighborʼs wife gains four things: a bad rep­u­ta­tion, poor sleep, pun­ish­ment, and hell.

There is bad rep­u­ta­tion, an evil des­ti­na­tion, the brief pleas­ure of the fright­ened man and wom­an, and the king imposes a heav­y pun­ish­ment. There­fore, let no man lie down with his neighborʼs wife.
Just as a blade of grass, if wrong­ly han­dled, cuts the hand, so does as­cet­i­cism, if wrong­ly prac­tised, lead to hell.
An act performed care­less­ly, a bro­ken vow, and ques­tion­a­ble cel­i­ba­cy, none of these bring much re­ward.
If any­thing is to be done, then do it vig­or­ous­ly. A care­less pil­grim on­ly scatters the dust of his passions more wide­ly.
It is bet­ter not to do an evil deed, for an evil deed torments a man af­ter­wards. It is bet­ter to do a good deed, for hav­ing done it, one is not tormented.
Like a fron­tier fort with defences in­side and out, so let a man guard him­self. Do not let a mo­ment pass by, for they who al­low the right mo­ment to pass, suf­fer pain when consigned to hell.
They who are a­shamed of what is not shame­ful, and are not a­shamed of what is shame­ful, such men, em­brac­ing false doctrines go to an evil des­ti­na­tion.
They who see dan­ger where there is none, and see no dan­ger where there is, such men, em­brac­ing false doctrines go to an evil des­ti­na­tion.
They who see wrong where there is none, and see no wrong where there is, such men, em­brac­ing false doctrines go to an evil des­ti­na­tion.
They who see wrong as wrong, and see right as right, such men, em­brac­ing true doc­trine go to a good des­ti­na­tion.
As an el­e­phant in bat­tle endures an ar­row shot from a bow, so will I en­dure def­a­ma­tion. Man­y peo­ple lack vir­tue.
They on­ly lead a tamed el­e­phant in­to crowds. The king on­ly rides a tamed el­e­phant. The tamed man who endures def­a­ma­tion is the best a­mong men.
Trained mules, thor­ough­bred hors­es, and elephants with large tusks are ex­cel­lent, but he who tames him­self is bet­ter still.
For with these animals no man reaches the un­trod­den coun­try, where a tamed man goes by tam­ing him­self.
The el­e­phant called Dhanapalaka, deep in rut, is dif­fi­cult to hold. He does not eat a mor­sel in cap­tiv­i­ty, but longs for the el­e­phant grove.
When a man is in­ac­tive and glut­ton­ous, sleep­ing and roll­ing a­round in bed like an o­ver­fed hog, that fool is born a­gain and a­gain.
This mind used to wan­der a­bout as it liked, wher­ev­er it wished, how­ev­er it pleased. Now I will hold it in check, as a rid­er with a hook controls an el­e­phant in rut.
De­light in mind­ful­ness. Watch o­ver your mind. Lift your­self out of the evil way, as an el­e­phant lifts it­self out of the mud.
If you find a wise, pru­dent, and vir­tu­ous friend, then, o­ver­com­ing all dangers, walk with him joy­ful­ly and mind­ful­ly.
If you find no friend who is wise, pru­dent, and vir­tu­ous, then walk a­lone like a king leav­ing be­hind his king­dom, like an el­e­phant in the for­est.
It is bet­ter to live a­lone. There is no com­pan­ion­ship with a fool. Live a­lone, do no evil, and be con­tent, like an el­e­phant in the for­est.
These are good: friends when the need arises, con­tent­ment with what you have, mer­it in the hour of death, giv­ing up all grief,
serv­ing your moth­er, serv­ing your fa­ther, serv­ing monks, serv­ing ho­ly men,
vir­tue last­ing in­to old age, firm­ly root­ed faith, attaining dis­cern­ment, avoiding evil.
The crav­ing of a heed­less man grows like a creep­ing vine. He runs from life to life, like a mon­key seek­ing fruit in the for­est.
He who is o­ver­come by this vile and cling­ing crav­ing, his suf­fer­ing increases like grass af­ter rain.
He who overcomes this vile crav­ing, so dif­fi­cult to con­quer, suf­fer­ing falls off him like wa­ter drops from a lo­tus leaf.

To all as­sem­bled here I say, “Good luck. Dig up the root of crav­ing, like one seek­ing the sweet scented root of birana grass. Let not the temp­ter crush you a­gain and a­gain, as the stream crushes a reed.”
A tree will grow a­gain, e­ven if cut down, as long as its root is safe and firm. Thus, un­less la­tent crav­ing is destroyed, suf­fer­ing will re­turn a­gain and a­gain.
The thir­ty six streams of crav­ing flow to­wards pleas­ure. The mis­guid­ed man, in whom they flow strongly, is car­ried a­way.
The streams flow eve­ry­where. The creep­ing vines of crav­ing grow eve­ry­where. If you see the vine spring up, cut its root with knowl­edge.
Driv­en by crav­ing, men run a­bout like a snared rab­bit. Held by fetters and bonds, they suf­fer a­gain and a­gain for a long time.
Driv­en by crav­ing, men run a­bout like a snared rab­bit. So a monk should drive out crav­ing, and strive to be with­out pas­sion.
The wise do not say that a fet­ter made of i­ron, wood, or hemp is strong. Far stronger is a long­ing for jewels and ornaments, chil­dren and wives.

The wise say that a strong fet­ter drags one down, though seem­ing loose, it is dif­fi­cult to re­move. Af­ter hav­ing cut it, the wise are free from cares, and leave the world, desires, and pleasures be­hind.
Give up the past, the fu­ture, and the pres­ent, to cross to the oth­er shore of ex­ist­ence. If your mind is com­plete­ly free, you will not en­ter in­to birth and de­cay a­gain.
If a man is tossed a­bout by doubts, full of pas­sion, and fo­cused on pleas­ure, his crav­ing grows more and more. He makes his fetters strong, in­deed.
If a man delights in quieting doubts, is al­ways mind­ful, and meditates on the impurities, he will end crav­ing and cut the fet­ter of the temp­ter.
He who has reached the goal is with­out fear, is with­out crav­ing, is with­out blem­ish, and has re­moved all the thorns of life: this will be his last bod­y.
The gift of the law exceeds all gifts. The taste of the law exceeds all tastes. De­light in the law exceeds all delights. The ex­tinc­tion of crav­ing overcomes all suf­fer­ing.
Rich­es de­stroy the fool­ish, but not those who seek the be­yond. The fool, by crav­ing for rich­es, destroys him­self and others.
Weeds spoil a field. Pas­sion spoils a man. There­fore, a gift giv­en to those with­out pas­sion yields great fruit.
Weeds spoil a field. Ha­tred spoils a man. There­fore, a gift giv­en to those with­out ha­tred yields great fruit.
Weeds spoil a field. De­lu­sion spoils a man. There­fore, a gift giv­en to those with­out de­lu­sion yields great fruit.
Weeds spoil a field. De­sire spoils a man. There­fore, a gift giv­en to those with­out de­sire yields great fruit.
Good is re­straint o­ver the eye, o­ver the ear, o­ver the nose, and o­ver the tongue.
Good is re­straint in the bod­y, in speech, in mind, in all things. A monk, restrained in all things, is freed from all suf­fer­ing.
He who controls his hands, feet, and speech; who is well con­trolled, delights in the in­ward, is col­lect­ed, sol­i­tar­y and con­tent, him they call a monk.
The monk who controls his tongue, speaks mod­er­ate­ly and calm­ly, and teaches the law and its mean­ing, his speech is sweet.
The monk who abides in the law, delights in the law, meditates on the law, and keeps the law in mind, he will nev­er fall a­way from the true law.
Let him not des­pise what he has re­ceived, nor en­vy others. A monk who envies others does not ob­tain con­cen­tra­tion.
If a monk lives pure­ly, is dil­i­gent, and does not des­pise what he has re­ceived, though he receives lit­tle, then e­ven the gods will praise him.
The monk who abides in kind­ness, and is de­vot­ed to the teachings of Bud­dha, will at­tain peace, hap­pi­ness, and ces­sa­tion of nat­u­ral desires.
Monk, bail out this boat. Once bailed, it will sail light­ly. Hav­ing cut out pas­sion and ha­tred, you will reach Sal­va­tion.
Med­i­tate monk. Be mind­ful. Do not di­rect your mind to sen­su­al pleas­ure. Heed­less, do not swal­low the flam­ing i­ron ball lest you cry out when burn­ing, “This is suf­fer­ing.”
There is no med­i­ta­tion with­out in­sight. There is no in­sight with­out med­i­ta­tion. He who has in­sight and med­i­ta­tion is near Sal­va­tion.
A monk who has entered his emp­ty house, whose mind is tran­quil, and who sees the law clear­ly, feels a de­light more than hu­man.
Once he has con­sid­ered the or­i­gin and de­struc­tion of the elements of the bod­y, he finds hap­pi­ness and joy be­long­ing to those who know the im­mor­tal.
This is the be­gin­ning for a wise monk: guarding the sen­ses, con­tent­ment, re­straint un­der the law.
He should have friends who are no­ble, en­er­get­ic, and pure. He should be friend­ly, and skilled in con­duct. Then, hav­ing much joy, he will put an end to suf­fer­ing.
Shed pas­sion and ha­tred, O monks, as the jas­mine plant sheds its withered flowers.
That monk is called qui­et whose bod­y and speech and mind are calm, who is col­lect­ed, and who has purged the baits of the world.
Re­prove your­self and ex­am­ine your­self by your­self. By be­ing vig­i­lant and at­ten­tive, you will live hap­pi­ly.
You are your own mas­ter and ref­uge. There­fore, watch o­ver your­self as a mer­chant watches o­ver a good horse.
The monk who is full of joy, and who has faith in the teachings of Bud­dha will reach the qui­et place, ces­sa­tion of nat­u­ral desires, and hap­pi­ness.
E­ven a young monk who applies him­self to the teachings of Bud­dha brightens this world, like the moon set free from clouds.
He who is mind­ful, blame­less, settled, du­ti­ful, with­out passions, and who has attained the highest goal, him I call a ho­ly man.
The sun shines by day, the moon shines by night, the war­ri­or shines in ar­mor, the ho­ly man shines in med­i­ta­tion. But the Awakened One shines with splen­dor day and night.
A man is called ho­ly for discarding evil, con­tem­pla­tive for walk­ing qui­et­ly, a pil­grim for leav­ing his own impurities.
No one should at­tack a ho­ly man, but no ho­ly man, if attacked, should give in to his an­ger. Shame on him who attacks a ho­ly man, but more shame to him who gives in to his an­ger.
Noth­ing is bet­ter for a ho­ly man than to hold his mind back from the pleasures of life. When all de­sire to in­jure has vanished, pain ceases.
I call him a ho­ly man who does not of­fend in bod­y, word, or mind, and is restrained on these three points.
Re­vere that teach­er who has taught you the law as taught by the Bud­dha, just as a ho­ly man­y reveres the sac­ri­fi­cial fire.
A man does not be­come ho­ly by his mat­ted hair, by his fam­i­ly, or by birth. He in whom there is truth and right­eous­ness, he is pure, he is a ho­ly man.
What use is mat­ted hair, O fool? What use is your coat of goat skins? The tan­gle is with­in you, but you comb the out­side.
I call him a ho­ly man who has cut eve­ry fet­ter, is fear­less, in­de­pend­ent and unshackled.
I call him a ho­ly man who, with­out an­ger, endures in­sult, im­pris­on­ment, and beat­ing, who has pa­tience like the strength of an ar­my.
I call him a ho­ly man who is free from an­ger, du­ti­ful, vir­tu­ous, with­out crav­ing, sub­dued, and who has re­ceived his last bod­y.
I call him a ho­ly man who does not cling to pleasures, like wa­ter on a lo­tus leaf or a mus­tard seed on the tip of a nee­dle.
I call him a ho­ly man who, e­ven here, discerns the end of his suf­fer­ing, has put down his bur­den, and is unshackled.
I call him a ho­ly man who is wise, has deep un­der­stand­ing, discerns the right and wrong path, and has reached the ul­ti­mate goal.
I call him a ho­ly man who keeps a­loof from both laymen and as­cet­ic, who has no per­ma­nent home, and few desires.
I call him a ho­ly man who renounces vi­o­lence to­wards all beings, wheth­er weak or strong, and nei­ther kills nor causes others to kill.
I call him a ho­ly man from whom pas­sion and ha­tred, pride and en­vy have dropped like a mus­tard seed from the tip of a nee­dle.
I call him a ho­ly man who speaks true and in­struc­tive words, free from harsh­ness, so that he offends no one.
I call him a ho­ly man who on­ly takes what is giv­en to him, be it long or short, small or large, good or bad.
I call him a ho­ly man who, in this world, is a­bove at­tach­ment to mer­it and evil, is with­out grief, stain­less, and pure.
I call him a ho­ly man who, leav­ing all crav­ing, travels with­out a home, and in whom all crav­ing is ex­tinct.
I call him a ho­ly man who, af­ter leav­ing all at­tach­ment to men, has ris­en a­bove all at­tach­ment to the gods, and is free from eve­ry at­tach­ment.
I call him a ho­ly man who does not cling to past, pres­ent, or fu­ture, who has noth­ing, who clings to noth­ing.
I call him a ho­ly man, the fear­less, the no­ble, the he­ro­ic, the great sage, the con­quer­or, the pas­sion­less, the pure, the awakened.
I call him a ho­ly man who knows his form­er lives, who sees heav­en and hell, has reached the end of births, is per­fect in knowl­edge, a sage, and who has mastered all there is to mas­ter.
